    • Using tenzing as a package

Using tenzing as a package

Source: vignettes/local_use.Rmd
local_use.Rmd

If you do not want to use the tenzing app, you can use the package from R to achieve the same outputs.

Setup

First, you have to install the package.

# install.packages("devtools")
 devtools::install_github("marton-balazs-kovacs/tenzing")

Second you have to load the package.

library(tenzing)

Create your infosheet

The infosheet template is built in the package, as well as uploaded to the net. If you choose to fill out the template with your credit information locally, you can write the infosheet template as an xlsx file to your working directory from the package with the following code:

# install.packages("writexl")
writexl::write_xlsx(infosheet_template, "my_infosheet.xlsx")

To get more information on the infosheet tempalte use the ?tenzing::infosheet_template command.

Note: This produces the same result as downloading the infosheet template from the link provided before.

Load your infosheet

You can load the infosheet into R with the tenzing::read_infosheet function. This function accepts files with csv, tsv and xlsx extensions. As an example we will use the built in infosheet template.

my_infosheet <- read_infosheet(infosheet_path = "full_path_to_my_infosheet_with_extension")

After loading your infosheet you have to check its validity.

check_result <- validate_infosheet(infosheet = infosheet_template)

The validation function checks your infosheet by 10 statements. You can learn more about these checks by running the following code ?tenzing::infosheet_template.

The check can have three results: success, warning or error. You can investigate what was the output of each of the 10 checks.

purrr::map(check_result, "type")
#> $missing_surname
#> [1] "success"
#> 
#> $missing_firstname
#> [1] "success"
#> 
#> $duplicate_names
#> [1] "success"
#> 
#> $duplicate_initials
#> [1] "success"
#> 
#> $missing_order
#> [1] "success"
#> 
#> $duplicate_order
#> [1] "success"
#> 
#> $missing_affiliation
#> [1] "success"
#> 
#> $missing_corresponding
#> [1] "success"
#> 
#> $missing_email
#> [1] "warning"
#> 
#> $missing_credit
#> [1] "success"

If any of them is an error than the output that you will generate in the next step will be corroborated. Therefore, you have to read the messages that are accompanied with the erroneous checks and update your infosheet accordingly.

purrr::map(check_result, "message")
#> $missing_surname
#> [1] "There are no missing surnames."
#> 
#> $missing_firstname
#> [1] "There are no missing firstnames."
#> 
#> $duplicate_names
#> [1] "There are no duplicate names in the infosheet."
#> 
#> $duplicate_initials
#> [1] "There are no duplicate initials in the infosheet."
#> 
#> $missing_order
#> [1] "There are no missing values in the order of publication."
#> 
#> $duplicate_order
#> [1] "There are no duplicated order numbers in the infosheet."
#> 
#> $missing_affiliation
#> [1] "There are no missing affiliations in the infosheet."
#> 
#> $missing_corresponding
#> [1] "There is at least one author indicated as corresponding author."
#> 
#> $missing_email
#> There is no email address provided for the corresponding author(s): 2
#> 
#> $missing_credit
#> [1] "All authors have at least one CRediT statement checked."

Generate output

If your infosheet is validated you can move on to output generation. There are four different types of outputs that you can create with the tenzing app.

create a human readable report of the contributions

print_roles_readable(infosheet = infosheet_template)
#> [1] "**Conceptualization:** Alex Holcombe, Balazs Aczel.  \n**Data Curation:** Marton Kovacs.  \n**Funding Acquisition:** Balazs Aczel.  \n**Investigation:** Balazs Aczel.  \n**Software:** Alex Holcombe.  \n**Supervision:** Alex Holcombe.  \n**Validation:** Alex Holcombe.  \n**Visualization:** Balazs Aczel.  \n**Writing - Original Draft Preparation:** Alex Holcombe.  \n**Writing - Review & Editing:** Alex Holcombe."

Create the contributorsâ€™ affiliation page

print_contrib_affil(infosheet = infosheet_template)
#> $contrib
#> Alex Holcombe^1^, Marton Kovacs^2^, Balazs Aczel^2^
#> 
#> $affil
#> ^1^University of Sydney, ^2^Institute of Psychology, ELTE, Eotvos Lorand University, Budapest, Hungary

Create a JATS formatted XML document containing the contributors information

print_xml(infosheet = infosheet_template)
#> {xml_document}
#> <contrib-group>
#> [1] <contrib>\n  <name surname="Aczel" given-names="Balazs"/>\n  <role vocab= ...
#> [2] <contrib>\n  <name surname="Holcombe" given-names="Alex"/>\n  <role vocab ...
#> [3] <contrib>\n  <name surname="Kovacs" given-names="Marton"/>\n  <role vocab ...

Create a YAML document containing the contributors informtation

This output can be incorporated into manuscript created with the papaja package.

print_yaml(infosheet = infosheet_template)
#> [1] "author:\n  - name: Alex Holcombe\n    affiliation: '1'\n    role:\n      - Conceptualization\n      - Software\n      - Supervision\n      - Validation\n      - Writing - Original Draft Preparation\n      - Writing - Review & Editing\n  - name: Marton Kovacs\n    affiliation: '2'\n    role: Data Curation\n    corresponding: yes\n    address: Enter postal address here\n  - name: Balazs Aczel\n    affiliation: '2'\n    role:\n      - Conceptualization\n      - Funding Acquisition\n      - Investigation\n      - Visualization\n\naffiliation:\n  - id: '1'\n    institution: University of Sydney\n  - id: '2'\n    institution: Institute of Psychology, ELTE, Eotvos Lorand University, Budapest,\n      Hungary\n"
